TEXT.S: Top world news stories for Tuesday at 0500 GMT:

Mideast-Israel-politics-Sharon JERUSALEM: Doctors treating Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon were monitoring his body's responses as they continued to ease him out of a coma buoyed by initial signs he had retained at least some brain function after last week's massive stroke.

Mideast-Palestinian-vote-Jerusalem JERUSALEM: Israel agreed to allow Arabs in east Jerusalem to vote in this month's parliamentary election, as Palestinian leader Mahmud Abbas said the polls would take place on January 25 as scheduled.

Health-flu-Turkey DOGUBEYAZIT, Turkey: An angry crowd mobbed Turkey's health minister in this remote eastern town, home of the country's first bird flu deaths, as Ankara reported more human cases of the lethal disease, raising alarms over its menacing westward advance.

Iraq BAGHDAD: At least 28 policemen were killed and 25 injured when twin suicide bombers attacked Iraq's interior ministry where ministers and the US ambassador were attending a parade to mark Police Day.

Iran-nuclear-politics TEHRAN: Iran said it would resume nuclear fuel research, triggering fresh Western warnings that Tehran could face sanctions and wreck dialogue to end a dispute over its controversial nuclear programme.

US-Cheney-health WASHINGTON: US Vice President Dick Cheney went to hospital for a few hours suffering shortness of breath, but President George W. Bush said his trusted deputy was "doing fine" and would quickly go back to work.

Iraq-vote-politics BAGHDAD: Talks were under way to form a government that bridges Iraq's sectarian divide, with the United States and Britain reaching out to the minority Sunni Arabs who cried foul following December's elections.

US-Iraq-journalist-kidnap WASHINGTON: The Christian Science Monitor newspaper pleaded for the release of American reporter Jill Carroll, seized in Baghdad by abductors who gunned down her Iraqi translator.

UN-Eritrea-Ethiopia-US UNITED NATIONS: The United States is sending a high-level team to Eritrea and Ethiopia to try to resolve a festering border dispute that threatens to degenerate into a new war between the two Horn of Africa arch-rivals, the US envoy to the UN said.

Health-SKorea-stemcell-technology SEOUL: South Korea's discredicted cloning pioneer Hwang Woo-Suk made no breakthrough in cloning technology, said a panel of experts, rejecting claims that Hwang had revolutionized stem cell research.
Health-SKorea-stemcell-crime SEOUL: Prosecutors said they would launch a criminal investigation into South Korea's discredited cloning expert Hwang Woo-Suk.
